comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @sh0375 Could you please add more descriptions?

comments.author: sh0375
comments.body: Problem is that powershell process has a lot of child processes. Why this happens and how to avoid it? What description can I add?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: The product uses a number of threads - explain what problems it causes? Which scenario does not work or is slow, failed, bad?

comments.author: sh0375
comments.body: I'm using 10 powershell processes for serving commands. But each process creates 21 child processes. As result I have 10*22=220 processes and memory in system finishes. Is there a way to predict maximum number of child processes, powershell can create? How much RAM is required for powershell process, so that it could create all necessary child processes?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
The processes themselves do not consume a lot of resources. Resources consumes what works within them. In some cases, we really consume a lot of resources when we work with file system or output formatting. Partly it depends on the .Net Core 2.0.0 we use - they are already working on optimization and with release version 2.1.0 we will automatically work faster and better use resources. After that I hope we will also optimize inside PowerShell Core.
Also you use cmdlets from additional modules - they themselves can be implemented so that consume a lot of resources and should be optimized too.
